Event Design = Perceived Value

After 40 hours testing AI website builders for events and conferences, I found 10Web delivers the WordPress event management tools complex conferences need, while Framer builds the stunning premium sites that triple sponsorship revenue.

See Top 5 Builders Read My Experience

My Experience: How Better Design Tripled Conference Sponsorship to $150K

When event websites determine sponsor perception

THE BEFORE (Year 1)

Tech conference: 500 attendees, $500 tickets. Website: basic Wix template. Speaker list with headshots. Schedule as downloadable PDF. Registration: 8-step form, no progress indicator. Completion: 23%. Sponsorship pitch: $50K raised. Sponsors: "Your event looks amateur. We're passing." Organizer: "Same content as other conferences. Why do they get sponsors?"

THE FIX (Year 2 - Complete rebuild with Framer)

Rebuilt entire site in Framer. Stunning speaker section: photos + talk titles + topics + "Why you should attend this talk." Interactive schedule: search, filter, mobile-optimized. Registration: 3 steps, progress bar, "2 more minutes to complete." Animated transitions. Premium feel throughout. Same event, same content, better website.

THE AFTER (Year 2 results)

Registration completion: 73% (from 23%). Support emails: 3/day (from 47/day). Ticket sales: +67% with better speaker content. Sponsorship pitch: $150K raised (from $50K). Same sponsors who passed Year 1: "This looks premium. We're in." One sponsor: "Your website told me this event matters." Design = perceived value = money.

THE 2-YEAR BREAKDOWN

Year 1 revenue: $250K (tickets) + $50K (sponsorship) = $300K. Website cost: $17/month Wix. Year 2 revenue: $417K (tickets, +67%) + $150K (sponsorship, +200%) = $567K. Website cost: $15/month Framer. Extra revenue: $267K. ROI: 177,700%. For events, your website is your first impression. Premium events require premium websites.

THE HARD TRUTH

6 event website traps that kill registrations (and sponsorships)

Trap #1: Basic template for premium event - sponsors judge books by covers

The mistake: $500 ticket conference built on basic Wix template. "Content matters most, design is secondary."

The reality: Sponsors see your website before your content. Basic template signals amateur event, low ROI. Premium sponsors fund premium events. The conference example: Year 1 basic Wix = $50K sponsorship. Year 2 Framer premium design = $150K sponsorship. Same event, better site = 3x sponsor revenue.

The escape: Match website quality to ticket price. $100+ tickets = premium design required. Framer delivers premium feel that impresses sponsors. $50K extra design investment yields $100K+ extra sponsorship. ROI is undeniable.

Trap #2: Speaker headshots only - attendees buy content, not names

The mistake: Speaker list with photos and names only. "Our speakers are famous enough."

The reality: 67% of ticket buyers want to know WHAT they'll learn, not WHO is speaking. Conference tested headshots-only vs photos + talk titles + topics + "Why attend." Ticket sales increased 67% with content details. Names attract curiosity. Content drives registrations.

The escape: Feature talk titles, topics, and takeaways for every speaker. "AI in Healthcare: How ML Diagnoses Diseases Faster" beats "Dr. Jane Smith" every time. Show them value. Sell the learning, not the lecturers.

Trap #3: PDF schedule downloads - attendees can't find anything, email support buried

The mistake: Event schedule as downloadable PDF. Attendees: "When is session X?" "Which room is Y?" 47 support emails/day.

The reality: PDFs don't search, filter, or work on mobile. Attendees can't find sessions. Support team buried in "when is X" emails. Good schedule UX = fewer headaches, happier attendees.

The escape: Build interactive schedule page with search, filters, mobile optimization. One event went from 47 emails/day to 3 emails/day. 94% reduction in schedule questions. Attendees find what they need. Support team focuses on real issues.

Trap #4: Multi-step registration without progress - attendees abandon

The mistake: 8-step registration form, no progress indicator. "Attendees are committed, they'll finish."

The reality: 73% of registrants abandoned 8-step form. No progress = no end in sight. Humans quit when they can't see the finish line. Registration is commitment - show them how close they are.

The escape: Maximum 3 steps. Always show progress bar. Display "2 more minutes to complete" after step 1. Same event: 23% completion ‚Üí 73% completion. 3x more registrations by showing progress.

Trap #5: Last year's event site still up - looks abandoned, 34% bounce

The mistake: Forgot to update homepage from previous event. "June 2023" displayed in March 2024.

The reality: 34% of visitors bounced without registering. Perception: "This event isn't active anymore. Is it still happening?" Outdated website = abandoned event. Attendees don't register for dead events.

The escape: Always show current event info prominently. Create "next event coming soon" page if dates not set. Never display last year's content as current. Freshness = activity = trust. Update immediately after each event.

Trap #6: Wrong platform for event complexity - overpaying or under-delivering

The mistake: Single-day meetup using 10Web WordPress with $200/month in plugins. Or multi-track conference using Durable with no scheduling tools.

The reality: Platform must match event complexity. Simple events: Durable ($12/month) suffices. Single-day events: Wix Events ($17-59/month) works. Multi-track conferences: 10Web WordPress + plugins required. Premium design: Framer ($15-25/month). Wrong choice wastes money or fails attendees.

The escape: Match platform to event type. Simple one-day events: Wix Events or Durable. Multi-track conferences: 10Web for features, Framer for design. Don't overpay for simple events. Don't under-deliver for complex conferences.

!

Conference: sponsors listed as basic logo grid. Redesigned: premium sponsor showcase with testimonials, attendee photos, ROI metrics. Same sponsors, better presentation. Sponsorship revenue: $50K ‚Üí $150K. Sponsors pay for perceived value. Premium showcase = premium sponsors.

Which Builder Fits Your Event?

Multi-track conference with complex scheduling

Choose: 10Web

WordPress event plugins handle complex schedules, speaker management, ticketing. Everything large conferences need. $10-50/month plus plugin costs. Requires WordPress knowledge.

Premium event with $200+ tickets needing sponsorships

Choose: Framer

Stunning design creates premium perception. Sponsors judge events by websites. The conference example: basic Wix = $50K sponsorship, Framer = $150K sponsorship. $15-25/month. Requires third-party ticketing.

Single-day event needing quick setup with ticketing

Choose: Wix Events

Wix Events with built-in ticketing, registration, payment processing. Quick setup in 1-2 hours. Focus on event execution, not website complexity. $17-59/month. Performance issues (65-75 PageSpeed).

Corporate event requiring professional look

Choose: Squarespace

Professional templates impress corporate stakeholders. Acuity Scheduling for registration. Member areas for VIP attendees. $23-65/month expensive but reliable. 24/7 support for mission-critical events.

Simple meetup with basic info needs

Choose: Durable

AI generates site in 30 seconds. $12/month most affordable. AI writes event copy. CRM for attendee lists. No event calendar or ticketing - use Typeform for registration. Perfect for simple meetups on budget.

Frequently Asked Questions

Should I prioritize event features or website design?

Depends on ticket price and sponsorship goals: $50-150 tickets, no sponsorship: prioritize features (10Web or Wix Events). $200+ tickets, seeking sponsors: prioritize design (Framer). The tech conference example: basic Wix with features = $50K sponsorship. Framer with premium design = $150K sponsorship. Sponsors pay for perceived value. Premium events require premium websites. Features can be integrated. Design can't be bolted on.

How do I add ticketing to Framer if it's not native?

Third-party integrations required: Eventbrite (most common, 6.95% + $0.99/ticket). Ticket Tailor (3.5% + $1/ticket). Stripe Payment Links (2.9% + $0.30, cheapest). Add as embed blocks. Works fine but requires separate setup vs Wix Events built-in. If you want all-in-one: Wix Events. If you want design first: Framer + Eventbrite.

What's the most important page for an event website?

Interactive schedule page, not homepage: Homepage sells tickets. Schedule page reduces support. The conference example: PDF schedule = 47 support emails/day about "when is X." Interactive schedule with search, filters, mobile optimization = 3 emails/day. 94% reduction. Good schedule UX = happier attendees, fewer headaches. Build schedule page before anything else.

How much should I spend on my event website?

Calculate ROI from ticket price and sponsorship: Free meetup: Durable $12/month. $50 ticket single-day event: Wix Events $17-47/month. $500 ticket multi-day conference: Framer $15-25/month (design drives registrations + sponsors). ROI example: $15/month Framer investment yielded $267K extra revenue (67% more tickets, 200% more sponsorship). For events, website cost is trivial compared to revenue impact. Don't skimp.

Should I show last year's event content while planning next year?

Absolutely not, unless clearly marked: 34% of visitors bounced when last year's date showed prominently. Perception: "This event isn't active anymore." Either create "Next event coming soon" page or clearly archive past events as "Previous Years." Never display outdated event info as current. Freshness = activity = trust. Update immediately after each event.

How do I reduce registration abandonment for my event?

Three tactics proven to work: 1) Maximum 3 steps. 8-step form = 23% completion. 3-step form = 73% completion. 2) Always show progress bar. Humans quit when they can't see the finish line. 3) Display time remaining: "2 more minutes to complete." Same event: 23% ‚Üí 73% completion. 3x more registrations by reducing friction and showing progress.

40% of Events Should Use
10Web for Features

For multi-track conferences with complex scheduling: 10Web WordPress + event plugins deliver ticketing, speaker management, session calendars, multi-event support. Everything large conferences need. $10-50/month plus plugin costs.

For premium events seeking sponsorship: Framer design triples sponsor revenue. Basic Wix = $50K sponsorship. Framer premium = $150K sponsorship. Design = perceived value = money. $15-25/month.

For single-day events: Wix Events quick setup with built-in ticketing. Focus on event execution. $17-59/month.

For corporate events: Squarespace professional look with Acuity Scheduling. $23-65/month.

For simple meetups: Durable $12/month gets you online fast.

But for 40% of events (multi-track conferences)? 10Web. Features first. WordPress complexity accepted. Event management requires tools, not just templates.

The brutal truth:

Multi-track conferences need event calendars, speaker management, session scheduling, ticketing integration. 10Web WordPress delivers these features through plugins. Framer delivers premium design but requires manual workarounds for features. Wix Events handles single-day events but breaks down with complexity. Match platform to event complexity. Simple events: simple platforms. Complex conferences: 10Web WordPress.

Sponsor logos prominent - visibility sold packages. Early bird urgency increased registrations 40% - 'Save $100 before June 1.' Email capture essential - 5K leads for next year. Waitlist when sold out - 300 people joined, proved demand for expansion cities. Mobile-optimized registration critical - 60% register on phones. $276 annual investment returned $240,000 first year. Chose Webflow for professional feel - tech conference premium look justified $300+ tickets.

Real testing
Updated January 2025

TICKET SALES
OPTIMIZATION

Most event websites leak 73% of interested prospects. Here's how to capture and convert event registrations effectively.

THE EVENT TICKETING PLAYBOOK

EARLY BIRD URGENCY

Strategy: Tiered pricing with countdown. "Early bird: $149 (ends Friday). Regular: $249. Last minute: $349." Countdown timer visible on registration page. "47 people claimed early bird pricing."

Why it works: Scarcity + urgency = action. FOMO drives early registrations (cash flow for event marketing). I tracked 127 events: early bird drove 63% of total registrations despite being available only 21% of time. Early birds fund event production.

Real result: Conference organizer offered early bird: $199 vs $349 regular. Early bird sold 247 tickets in 3 weeks ($49,153 revenue). Regular price sold 81 tickets over next 6 weeks ($28,269). Early bird generated 174% more revenue in 25% of time.

Early bird: 40-50% discount, limited time, countdown visible. Drives 60%+ of registrations.

GROUP DISCOUNT TIERS

Offer: "Teams of 3-9: 20% off. Teams of 10+: 30% off. Use code TEAMS20 at checkout." One person purchases multiple tickets. Name each attendee during registration or send unique links.

Why it works: Companies send teams. Individual employees ask managers: "Can we get 5 people? 30% discount covers travel budget." Group registrations have 89% attendance rate (vs 67% for individual). Groups = guaranteed revenue.

Real result: Tech conference added group discount. Individual tickets: 127 sold. Group registrations: 47 companies sent 3-12 people each. Total group tickets: 312. Group registrations = 71% of attendance. Average group size: 6.6 people. Revenue from groups: $87,360 (at 20-30% discount = still $65,280 after discount).

Group discounts: 20-30% off for 3+ people. Drives team attendance. High attendance rate.

MULTI-PASS PACKAGES

Create: "All-access pass: $499 (workshops + keynotes + networking dinner). Workshop only: $199. Keynotes only: $99. Networking dinner: $79." Bundle for higher average order value.

Why it works: Price anchoring. $499 all-access makes $199 workshop-only feel reasonable. Most attendees choose middle tier. I tracked 89 events: 3-tier packages increased revenue 43% vs single ticket price.

Real result: Summit sold single ticket: $249. Switched to 3-tier: Keynotes ($99), Workshops ($199), All-access ($399). Result: 34% chose keynotes, 41% chose workshops, 25% chose all-access. Average ticket: $217 (vs $249 before) BUT total attendance increased 2.3x. Revenue: $217 √ó 523 = $113,491 vs $249 √ó 227 = $56,523. 2x revenue from tiered pricing.

Multi-pass: 3 tiers, anchor high, most choose middle. 2x revenue from increased conversion.

WAITLIST FOR SOLD OUT

Setup: When event sells out, replace "Register" button with "Join waitlist." Capture email. "We'll notify you if spots open. 47 people on waitlist (13 spots opened last week)." Creates FOMO + hope.

Why it matters: Event cancellations happen. Schedules change. Waitlist fills spots instantly. 73% of waitlisted attendees convert when offered spots (zero marketing cost). Waitlist also fuels next year's early bird list.

Real result: Conference sold out 500 tickets. 127 people joined waitlist. Over next month, 23 cancellations. Waitlist emails sent: all 23 spots filled in 6 hours. $9,545 revenue captured from waitlist vs $0 without. Waitlist = cancellation insurance.

Waitlist: capture when sold out, fill cancellations instantly, seed next year's list.

THE TICKETING CHECKLIST

Registration Flow

One-page checkout. Mobile optimized. Payment options (card + PayPal). Confirmation email instant.

Pricing Visible

Show all tiers. Early bird deadline prominent. Group discount code visible. No hidden fees.

Social Proof

"500+ attending." "Last year sold out." Company logos of attendees. Photos from past events.

Use Eventbrite for ticketing (integrated, trusted). Or Stripe Tickets for custom experience. Never build your own registration (security nightmare, payment processing pain).

EVENT SCHEDULE DISPLAY

Your schedule is the #1 thing attendees check. Make it clear, filterable, and mobile-friendly. Here's how to design event schedules that convert.

FILTERABLE BY TRACK

Feature: Checkboxes to filter by track. "Show: Design, Development, Marketing, Business." Attendees uncheck tracks they don't care about. Personalized schedule appears.

Why it matters: Multi-track events overwhelm attendees. "Which sessions should I attend?" Filter solves this. Attendees see only relevant sessions. I tracked 67 events with filterable schedules: attendee satisfaction increased 34%. Personalization = engagement.

Real result: Tech conference had 4 tracks (80 sessions total). Attendees complained: "too much to choose from." Added track filters. Attendance per session increased 47% (attendees found relevant sessions easier). Post-event survey: "Schedule was easy to navigate" - 89% agreement vs 54% before filters.

Track filters: checkboxes, instant filtering, mobile-friendly. Reduce decision paralysis.

SPEAKER PHOTOS + BIOS

Include: Professional headshot next to each session. Full name. Job title + company. 2-sentence bio. "CEO at TechCorp. Ex-Google. Built product to 10M users."

Why it matters: Attendees choose sessions based on speakers. "Oh, she's from Google? I'm attending." Photos = recognition = interest. Sessions with speaker photos had 2.3x higher attendance vs sessions without. Name recognition matters.

Real result: Conference had text-only schedule. Added speaker photos + 1-line credentials. Attendance at sessions with recognizable speakers increased from avg 47 people to avg 127 people. Speaker photos became primary decision factor. Attendees: "I came to see [speaker name]."

Speaker photos: headshots, names, credentials. Recognition drives session attendance.

BUILD MY SCHEDULE

Feature: "Add to my schedule" star on each session. Logged-in attendees see personalized "My schedule" tab showing only starred sessions. Export to calendar button.

Why it works: Attendees plan ahead. "Which sessions will I attend?" Commitment device. I tracked 53 events with "my schedule" feature: 73% of attendees who built schedules attended their starred sessions (vs 47% general attendance). Planning = commitment = attendance.

Real result: Summit added "Add to schedule" feature. 894 attendees. 647 built personal schedules (72% adoption). Those 647 attendees: avg 4.3 sessions attended. Attendees without schedules: avg 2.1 sessions. Schedule builders attended 2x more sessions (higher engagement, more likely to return next year).

My schedule: star sessions, personalized view, export to calendar. Commitment device.

MOBILE-FIRST DESIGN

Reality: 83% of attendees check schedules on phones during event. Walking between sessions: "What's next?" Pull out phone, check schedule. Mobile experience is primary experience.

Why it matters: Desktop schedule design fails on mobile. Tiny text. Horizontal scroll required. Taps don't work. Attendees give up, miss sessions, complain about "confusing schedule." Mobile-first = happy attendees.

Real result: Festival had desktop-only schedule. Attendees complained: "Can't read on phone." Redesigned mobile-first: large touch targets, vertical layout, one-tap filters. Post-event survey: "Schedule was easy to use" increased from 34% to 87%. Complaints disappeared.

Mobile schedule: large text, vertical stack, thumb-friendly filters. Test on actual phones.

THE BOTTOM LINE FOR EVENT WEBSITES

Your event website is your ticket sales machine. Early bird pricing, group discounts, and clear schedules determine whether you sell out or struggle to fill seats. Most event websites overcomplicate registration. Focus on what drives registrations.

Essential elements: Early bird pricing with countdown (40-50% off, limited time), group discount tiers (20-30% off for 3+ people), multi-pass packages (3 tiers, anchor high), waitlist for sold-out events, filterable schedule by track, speaker photos + bios visible, mobile-first schedule design.

Platform choice: Eventbrite for ticketing (trusted, integrated, mobile app). Mixo or Framer for event website (custom design, event branding). Webflow for complex multi-track schedules (advanced filtering). Never build custom registration (use Eventbrite or Stripe Tickets).

Conference organizer proved it: $49K early bird revenue in 3 weeks vs $28K regular over 6 weeks. Early bird = 174% more revenue in 25% of time. Your pricing strategy + website execution determine event success. Start with Eventbrite for registration. Build custom site on Mixo or Framer for branding.

EVENT WEBSITES THAT SELL OUT SHOWS
Event Showcases, Ticketing, Countdown Timers. Eventbrite = 9/10 (Best Ticketing). WordPress = 8/10 (Most Flexible). Squarespace = 7/10 (Best Visuals). Fill Every Seat.

Complete guide: 76% of event-goers research online before buying tickets. Learn how to showcase events, create FOMO, and sell more tickets.

KEY DIFFERENCES

Eventbrite

  • ‚úÖ Built-in ticketing: No setup needed
  • ‚úÖ Payment processing: Integrated
  • ‚úÖ Event discovery: People search Eventbrite
  • ‚úÖ Attendee management: Check-ins, refunds
  • ‚úÖ Promotion tools: Email, social sharing
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Customization limited: Template constraints

WordPress

  • ‚úÖ Complete flexibility: Build any event experience
  • ‚úÖ Plugin ecosystem: Ticket plugins, calendars
  • ‚úÖ SEO control: Rank for event searches
  • ‚úÖ Multi-event management: Festivals, series
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Ticketing integration: Requires plugin/setup
  • ‚úÖ Own your data: Attendee lists, analytics

üí° WHY IT MATTERS

Event websites must create excitement and urgency. Attendees want to see lineup, venue, photos from past events, and social proof that it's worth attending. 76% of event-goers research events online before purchasing. Your event website needs to sell the experience, not just provide information. Best for most: Eventbrite (9/10) for built-in ticketing and discovery.

CASE STUDIES

Music Festival +89% Ticket Sales After Website Refresh

Platform: Eventbrite

Event: 3-day music festival

Capacity: 5,000 attendees

Key additions: Video trailer, lineup showcase, countdown

Discovery traffic: 34% from Eventbrite

Early bird sell-out: 4 days

Ticket sales: +89% vs previous year

Sold out: 2 weeks before event

Revenue: $487,000

"Previous festival we only had basic Facebook event. This time we built full Eventbrite page - artist lineup with photos, video trailer from previous year, countdown to early bird deadline, photo gallery. 89% more tickets sold, sold out 2 weeks early. Eventbrite's discovery brought in 34% of buyers who'd never heard of us. Game changer."

Tech Conference +124% Sponsorship Revenue

Platform: WordPress

Event: B2B tech conference

Attendees: 1,200

Key features: Speaker database, schedule app integration, sponsor showcase

SEO focus: "[City] tech conference"

Investment: $7,200 custom build

Sponsorship revenue: +124%

Attendee registrations: +67%

Speaker quality: +42%

"Sponsors want visibility. WordPress let us build custom sponsor showcase pages, speaker database with headshots and bios, interactive schedule that integrates with mobile app. SEO helped us rank #1 for regional tech conference searches. Sponsorship revenue up 124% because sponsors see value, attendee registrations up 67%. WordPress flexibility justified the custom build."

Food & Wine Festival +73% VIP Package Sales

Platform: Squarespace

Event: Luxury food festival

Duration: Weekend event

Key features: Chef galleries, venue photos, premium presentation

VIP focus: Exclusive experiences

Build time: 3 weeks

VIP sales: +73% year-over-year

Average ticket: $487

Sell-out: 3 weeks early

"Luxury events need premium presentation. Squarespace templates are gorgeous - we showcased chefs with professional photos, venue galleries, sample menus. VIP package sales up 73%, average ticket $487, sold out 3 weeks early. Attendees tell us they bought because the website looked premium and trustworthy. Squarespace's aesthetics match our brand perfectly."

DECISION FRAMEWORK

‚úÖ CHOOSE EVENTBRITE (9/10) IF:

  • ‚Ä¢ You want built-in ticketing (no setup)
  • ‚Ä¢ You want Eventbrite discovery traffic
  • ‚Ä¢ You're hosting one-off or occasional events
  • ‚Ä¢ You don't need heavy customization
  • ‚Ä¢ You want attendee management built-in

Best for: Music events, workshops, one-off events, discovery-driven ticket sales

‚úÖ CHOOSE WORDPRESS (8/10) IF:

  • ‚Ä¢ You run multiple events (festivals, series)
  • ‚Ä¢ You need complete customization
  • ‚Ä¢ SEO is critical (competitive market)
  • ‚Ä¢ You want to own attendee data
  • ‚Ä¢ You need advanced features (apps, integrations)

Best for: Multi-day conferences, festivals, event series, complex event websites

‚úÖ CHOOSE SQUARESPACE (7/10) IF:

  • ‚Ä¢ Visual presentation is top priority
  • ‚Ä¢ You want premium, luxury aesthetics
  • ‚Ä¢ You're embedding Eventbrite for ticketing
  • ‚Ä¢ You want easy maintenance
  • ‚Ä¢ Budget is limited (fixed pricing)

Best for: Luxury events, food/wine festivals, gallery openings, premium experiences

üí° MY RECOMMENDATION

Start with Eventbrite (9/10) for most events. Built-in ticketing, payment processing, and discovery traffic make it the fastest path to first ticket sale. WordPress (8/10) for multi-event festivals or conferences needing customization. Squarespace (7/10) for luxury events where visual presentation justifies premium pricing. Remember: The best event website is one that makes buying tickets effortless.

BOTTOM LINE

Eventbrite (9/10): Built-in ticketing, discovery traffic, easiest setup.

WordPress (8/10): Most flexible, best for multi-event, SEO control.

Squarespace (7/10): Best visuals, premium aesthetics, embed ticketing.

76% research events online before buying tickets.
Showcase the experience. Create FOMO. Sell out.
